Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Collaborative Research: Broadband Wireless Access & Applications Center (BWAC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit

The proposed center seeks to establish a new Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) addressing broadband wireless access and applications. The center will focus on four areas: 1) enabling sharing up to many GHz of spectrum using technological advances and enabling platforms such as spectrum trading and auctions, and millimeter wave communications; 2) co-existence of heterogeneous devices (e.g. radar and communication systems); 3) providing connectivity for new applications such as wireless devices in the hospitals of the future, bringing wireless into the hospital in novel ways; and (d) improving electronic warfare technologies that address national-security issues.

Broader Impacts

The new center addresses an area of critical economic and has the potential to support development of broadband wirelss as a platform for innovation as addressed in the White House PCAST Report. The proposed center has the potential to link a diverse set of member companies across the broadband industry sector with university discovery in this area. Moreover, the center participants have a history of start-up initiation, and the opportunity from new starts to leverage the ecosystem created by the center is significant. The center plans to impact students via their conduct of center research, curriculum development and REU site development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
BWAC Phase I: Project Outcomes Report

 Since its inception in 2013, the Broadband Wireless Access & Applications Center (BWAC) continued to evolve into a strong multi-university I/UCRC that focuses on next-generation wireless systems. With some initial site turnover, BWAC converged to the following sites: The University of Arizona (lead), University of Notre Dame, Virginia Tech, University of Mississippi, and the Catholic University of America. The Center maintained a healthy industrial membership program, made up of more than 16 members, including 3 small companies, 9 large companies, U.S. government labs, and a non-profit organization. BWAC companies had representatives on the IAB and were actively involved in many aspects of the Center’s research, including defining thrust areas, project proposal formation, selecting projects, and monitoring progress.

Over the last 5 years, BWAC has been quite successful in training the next-generation engineering workforce for the wireless industry. BWAC’s faculty and students have published over 180 technical papers and graduated 31 PhD, 28 MS, and 5 BS students. Strong IAB involvement created numerous opportunities for students to work as interns at member companies, and many of them got hired by them. BWAC has made some progress in technology transfer, with more pending IP in the pipeline.  Specifically, in the 5-year period, 3 patents were awarded, 9 filed, and 10 invention disclosures reported. As BWAC matures, technology commercialization is expected to accelerate and spin-off companies are expected to form. Research done under BWAC funding is expected to have a broad impact on several industries in the areas of wireless communications and broadband access.  Summary of the center accomplishments and its broader impact in this area are as follows:

 

  • BWAC has funded over 62 projects over the past 5 years. These projects had significant impact on their domain of applications. As the Center matured, increased collaboration among the sites took place and close to half of the projects were collaborative. 
  • As a result of the Center’s research, we have made technical breakthroughs in topics related to wireless networking design, wireless security, antennas, RF transmitters and receivers, microwave and mmW circuits, 5G systems, signal intelligence, and software defined radios. This research has benefited the wireless industry in the development of smaller, cheaper, low-power, fast, and fully integrated wireless devices. 
  • Industry involvement in BWAC research created a synergy that accelerated technology development. This synergy has opened up new opportunities and funding for research even outside of the domain of BWAC. In his report about IAB feedback, the NSF evaluator, Dr. Denis Gray, states: “All of the members interviewed agreed that they had received both informal and, in some cases, very formal and concrete social networking/human capital benefits. In virtually all cases, members reported that they had developed new and valuable connections to faculty and other companies through their involvement with BWAC.” 

 UA Site Outcomes 

During Phase I, the UA site recruited eight distinct industry members, who contributed close to $800K in membership fees, along with in-kind contributions worth over $1M. BWAC@UA supported a total of 21 projects, involving 4 postdoctoral researchers, 16 graduate students, and several undergraduate students. BWAC’s seed funding was effectively leveraged to acquire substantially larger funding from US Government and industry. One notable example is the UA’s research project on securing wireless communications against malicious eavesdropping. This project started as a small BWAC project that led to new insights into the notion of information “leakage” through side-channel information and, consequently, novel techniques for countering meta-data-based eavesdropping. The scope of the project was expanded in several directions, with important defense and commercial applications. It eventually received more than $1.87M of non-BWAC funding. Other notable thrusts that were pursued by the UA site include massive MIMO systems, agile satellite communications, modulation classification, reconfigurable antennas, and hybrid beamforming.

BWAC@UA projects resulted in more than 35 published/accepted journal papers and 40 peer-reviewed conference papers. Several patents and invention disclosures have been filed based on this research. Under BWAC@UA’s support, 6 PhD and 8 MS students were graduated.

Site’s Contribution to Overall Center Operation and Management: UA has been the lead site for BWAC since its inception, charting the Center’s vision and roadmap. BWAC@UA has made valuable contributions to its industry affiliates, as evidenced by the very high membership retention rate, industry recruitment of UA graduates, and joint UA/industry collaboration on numerous large efforts (e.g., National Spectrum Consortium RFPs, DARPA programs, etc.). Interactions between BWAC@UA and its industry affiliates go beyond research funding efforts, and include joint publications, enrollment in the UA/ECE online MS program, part-time teaching at the UA by industry partners, sponsorship of undergraduate senior capstone projects, and serving on the advisory board for the ECE department. In Phase II, BWAC@UA plans to apply this university-industry model to new recruits, targeting a holistic relationship that is established on shared values and common interests.
